articles.headline: G.A.O. Report Says A.I.G. Is Stabilized
articles.snippet: Congress’s research arm said it was not yet clear whether the insurer could ever repay its federal rescue package.
articles.abstract: Congress’s research arm said it was not yet clear whether the insurer could ever repay its federal rescue package.
articles.lead_paragraph: The research arm of Congress reported on Monday that the American International Group’s financial condition had stabilized but that it was not clear whether the giant insurance group would ever be able to repay the federal government.

articles.headline: First Woman Ascends to Top Drill Sergeant Spot
articles.snippet: Command Sgt. Maj. Teresa L. King will become the first woman to run the Army’s drill sergeant school.
articles.abstract: Command Sgt. Maj. Teresa L. King will become the first woman to run the Army’s drill sergeant school.
articles.lead_paragraph: FORT JACKSON, S.C.  It may come as no surprise that the Army’s new top drill sergeant idolizes Gen. George S. Patton Jr., has jumped out of planes 33 times, aces every physical training test and drives a black Corvette with “noslack” vanity plates.

articles.headline: With Low Prices, Hyundai Builds Market Share
articles.snippet: The South Korean automaker benefited from the clunkers program and “went from the perception of cheap to an excellent value,” says one analyst.
articles.abstract: The South Korean automaker benefited from the clunkers program and “went from the perception of cheap to an excellent value,” says one analyst.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  It was not exactly a planned strategy, but the recession, particularly in the United States, has been very good for Hyundai, the South Korean automaker.

articles.headline: White House Takes Aggressive Role in State Races
articles.snippet: The intervention in the race for New York governor shows an assertiveness that worries some Democrats.
articles.abstract: The intervention in the race for New York governor shows an assertiveness that worries some Democrats.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The White House’s intervention in the race for New York governor is the latest evidence of how President Obama and his top advisers are taking an increasingly direct role in contests across the country, but their assertiveness has bruised some Democrats who suggest it could undercut Mr. Obama’s appeal with voters tired of partisan politics.
articles.byline: By Jeff Zeleny and Adam Nagourney

articles.headline: F.D.I.C. May Borrow Funds From Banks
articles.snippet: Bankers fear the alternative to the plan to have healthy banks lend billions to help the fund would be worse.
articles.abstract: Bankers fear the alternative to the plan to have healthy banks lend billions to help the fund would be worse.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Tired of the government bailing out banks? Get ready for this: officials may soon ask banks to bail out the government.

articles.headline: A $1 Million Research Bargain for Netflix, and Maybe a Model for Others
articles.snippet: Even the near-miss losers in the Netflix million-dollar-prize competition seemed to have few regrets.
articles.abstract: Even the near-miss losers in the Netflix million-dollar-prize competition seemed to have few regrets.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even the near-miss losers in the Netflix million-dollar-prize competition seemed to have few regrets.

articles.headline: A Pragmatist, Gates Reshapes Past Policies He Backed
articles.snippet: The White House is leaning heavily on Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, who brings stature and credibility to national security decisions.
articles.abstract: The White House is leaning heavily on Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates, who brings stature and credibility to national security decisions.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  On his tenth day on the job, Defense Secretary Robert M. Gates signed off on an ambitious if politically charged plan to build a new missile shield in Europe. Just two weeks later, he supported an even more wrenching decision to send additional American troops to Iraq, into a war that was not going well.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Thom Shanker

articles.headline: A Financier Peels Back the Curtain
articles.snippet: Guy Hands, perhaps best known for his unfortunate $4.73 billion purchase of EMI in 2007, offered an unvarnished appraisal of the private equity business.
articles.abstract: Guy Hands, perhaps best known for his unfortunate $4.73 billion purchase of EMI in 2007, offered an unvarnished appraisal of the private equity business.
articles.lead_paragraph: “We all had too much money. It was just too easy.”

articles.headline: China Spreads Aid in Africa, With a Catch
articles.snippet: Anticorruption crusaders complain that China’s foreign aid secrecy invites corruption, and that corruption debases the assistance.
articles.abstract: Anticorruption crusaders complain that China’s foreign aid secrecy invites corruption, and that corruption debases the assistance.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINDHOEK, Namibia  It is not every day that global leaders set foot in this southern African nation of gravel roads, towering sand dunes and a mere two million people. So when President Hu Jintao of China touched down here in February 2007 with a 130-person delegation in tow, it clearly was not just a courtesy call.
articles.byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and John Grobler

articles.headline: Bank of America Seeks to Pay Back Federal Aid
articles.snippet: The bank, under investigation by several agencies for its conduct while acquiring Merrill Lynch, is trying to smooth relations with regulators.
articles.abstract: The bank, under investigation by several agencies for its conduct while acquiring Merrill Lynch, is trying to smooth relations with regulators.
articles.lead_paragraph: One year and two bailouts later, Bank of America is moving to extricate itself from Washington’s grip.
